body: Concept ACK - moving back to vanilla / upstream Guix is good. I take that all of your patches have now made it back to upstream?

> I take that all of your patches have now made it back to upstream?

Yes, the [outstanding ones in 490e39f](https://github.com/dongcarl/guix/compare/490e39ff303f4f6873a04bfb8253755bdae1b29c) have made it upstream as of version-1.3.0.

Note that there are also a few other changes that made it in **_after_** version-1.3.0 that would remove some of our custom patching in `contrib/guix/patches`, but they were merged after a yet-unsolved [regression](https://issues.guix.gnu.org/48389) was introduced on Guix's master branch, so I think we should stay on version-1.3.0 for now.

> - Use 4.9 for all others (second-oldest LTS release, released in  combination with glibc glibc 2.24 in Debian stretch)

But we support back to glibc 2.17...? (And it supports much older kernels)
Kernel 4.19 for RISC-V 64 bit and 4.9 for the rest SGTM.
review ACK e6a94d44469f90f4dc88a07a5a8587730811c705 to change to vanilla guix. Did not review the kernel change.

> > * Use 4.9 for all others (second-oldest LTS release, released in  combination with glibc glibc 2.24 in Debian stretch)
> 
> But we support back to glibc 2.17...? (And it supports much older kernels)

With Gitian builds on Focal, we were building against kernel header version 5.4: https://packages.ubuntu.com/focal/linux-libc-dev, https://packages.ubuntu.com/focal/linux-libc-dev-riscv64-cross

I believe his change would be a strict improvement w/re compatibility.

0.21.1 used bionic, not focal. It appears to have Linux 4.15, so yes, it is still a compat improvement to use 4.9.

I don't care strongly either way, just making an observation.

As said in #bitcoin-core-dev I don't think it should matter much (for backwards compatibility) what version of the kernel we build against as long as libc is linked dynamically. That said it's good to settle on a version to build against, just to avoid variability that causes unpredictable issues.

The syscalls we use directly are:
- `getrandom` was introduced in kernel 3.17
- `perf_event_open` was introduced in Linux 2.6.31

So no problems there.

I did a build and get the same output as @hebasto.

ACK e6a94d44469f90f4dc88a07a5a8587730811c705
